Abraham.note: Patriarch of the Israelites, known for his covenant with God and father of Isaac.

Abel.note: Son of Adam and Eve, known for offering an acceptable sacrifice to God and being the first murder victim.

Abdeel.note: A minor biblical figure, father of Shelemiah in Jeremiah.

Abdi.note: Name of several minor Levites mentioned in Chronicles.

Abdiel.note: Name meaning 'servant of God,' listed among the leaders in Chronicles.

Abida.note: Descendant of Abraham through Midian, listed among tribal leaders.

Abiel.note: Grandfather of King Saul, mentioned in genealogies.

Abihu.note: Son of Aaron who died after offering unauthorized fire before the Lord.

Abijah.note: Multiple biblical figures; most notably a king of Judah and a priestly descendant of Aaron.

Abijam.note: King of Judah, known for continuing in the sins of his father Rehoboam.

Abimelech.note: Son of Gideon who declared himself king; notorious for his ruthless rise to power.

Abinadab.note: A man in whose house the Ark of the Covenant was kept.

Abinoam.note: Father of Barak, the military leader who worked with Deborah.

Abiram.note: Rebelled with Korah against Moses and was swallowed by the earth.

Abishag.note: Young woman who served King David in his old age; noted for her beauty.

Abishai.note: David’s nephew and loyal warrior, known for his bravery in battle.

Abital.note: One of King David’s wives and mother of Shephatiah.

Achbor.note: An official of King Josiah involved in rediscovering the Book of the Law.

Achish.note: Philistine king who gave refuge to David.

Adalia.note: One of the sons of Haman listed in the Book of Esther.

Adbeel.note: Son of Ishmael, mentioned in genealogies.

Addan.note: A man whose descendants returned from exile but could not prove their lineage.

Addi.note: Ancestor of Jesus mentioned in Luke's genealogy.

Adiel.note: A Levite listed in the genealogical records of Chronicles.

Adin.note: Head of a family that returned from Babylonian exile.

Adlai.note: Father of Shaphat, mentioned in a genealogical list.

Adna.note: Name of a priestly returnee from the Babylonian exile.

Adonijah.note: Son of David who attempted to take the throne before Solomon was crowned.

Adoram.note: Official over forced labor during the united and divided monarchy.

Adrammelech.note: Assyrian deity and the name of a son of King Sennacherib.

Ahab.note: King of Israel known for his idolatry and conflict with Elijah.

Ahaz.note: King of Judah who promoted idol worship and allied with Assyria.

Ahaziah.note: Name of both an Israelite and a Judahite king; both were ungodly rulers.

Ahasuerus.note: King of Persia, commonly identified with Xerxes, husband of Queen Esther.

Ahikam.note: Supporter of the prophet Jeremiah and protector of him during political unrest.

Ahimelech.note: High priest who gave David consecrated bread and was executed by Saul.

Ahinoam.note: Wife of King David and mother of his son Amnon.

Ahio.note: Son of Abinadab who helped guide the Ark when it was moved.

Aholibamah.note: Wife of Esau and daughter of Anah, mentioned in genealogies.

Almodad.note: Son of Joktan, mentioned in genealogies.

Amaziah.note: King of Judah known for his military exploits and eventual downfall.

Anah.note: Son of Zibeon and father of Aholibamah, mentioned in genealogies.

Ananias.note: Name of several individuals, including a high priest and a disciple in the Book of Acts.

Aran.note: Son of Aram and ancestor of the Arameans, mentioned in genealogies.

Archelaus.note: Son of Herod the Great, known for his cruelty and misrule.

Arcturus.note: Name of a star, possibly used metaphorically in biblical texts.

Arphaxad.note: Son of Shem and ancestor of Abraham, mentioned in genealogies.

Artemas.note: Possible companion of Paul, mentioned in the New Testament.

Asa.note: King of Judah known for his religious reforms and military victories.

Asaph.note: Levitical musician and author of several Psalms.

Asenath.note: Wife of Joseph and mother of Ephraim and Manasseh.

Athaliah.note: Queen of Judah who attempted to destroy the royal line but was overthrown.

Azariah.note: Name of several biblical figures, including a priest and one of Daniel's friends.

Azmaveth.note: Name of several individuals, including a warrior under David.

Barabbas.note: Criminal released by Pilate instead of Jesus.

Barnabas.note: Early Christian disciple and companion of Paul, known for encouragement.

Bartholomew.note: One of the twelve apostles; possibly the same as Nathanael.

Becher.note: Son of Benjamin; his descendants formed a tribe.

Benaiah.note: Mighty warrior under King David and later commander under Solomon.

Benjamin.note: Youngest son of Jacob, beloved brother of Joseph and progenitor of the tribe of Benjamin.

Baruch.note: Scribe and companion of the prophet Jeremiah.

Belshazzar.note: Babylonian king who saw the writing on the wall in the Book of Daniel.

Buz.note: Son of Nahor and Milcah, mentioned in genealogies.

Cain.note: Firstborn son of Adam and Eve who killed his brother Abel.

Cainan.note: Name shared by two figures in biblical genealogies.

Calcol.note: Wise man during Solomon’s time, mentioned for comparison.

Caleb.note: Faithful spy who trusted God and inherited Hebron.

Candace.note: Title for the queen of Ethiopia; her servant was baptized by Philip.

Carcas.note: One of the king’s eunuchs in the Book of Esther.

Careah.note: Father of Johanan, an army officer after the fall of Jerusalem.

Carmi.note: Several individuals; notably a son of Reuben and a descendant of Judah.

Carpus.note: Believer in Troas who hosted Paul’s cloak and books.

Carshena.note: One of the seven princes of Persia and Media under King Ahasuerus.

Cesar.note: Title used for Roman emperors, including Augustus and Tiberius.

Chedorlaomer.note: King of Elam who was defeated by Abraham.

Chelal.note: One of the sons listed among returnees from exile in Ezra.

Chelluh.note: Priestly family listed among those who married foreign wives in Ezra.

Chelub.note: Judahite leader, mentioned in genealogies (1 Chronicles 4:11).

Chelubai.note: Another name for Caleb, one of the faithful spies (1 Chronicles 2:9).

Chenaanah.note: Father of Zedekiah, a false prophet in Ahab’s court (1 Kings 22:11).

Chenani.note: Levite who participated in Ezra’s public reading of the Law (Nehemiah 9:4).

Chenaniah.note: Leader of Levites in music and temple worship (1 Chronicles 15:22).

Cheran.note: Son of Dishon and descendant of Seir the Horite (Genesis 36:26).

Chidon.note: Location where Uzzah was struck for touching the Ark (1 Chronicles 13:9).

Chilion.note: Son of Elimelech and Naomi; husband of Orpah (Ruth 1:2).

Chimham.note: Loyal follower of David who received land near Bethlehem (2 Samuel 19:37–40).

Chloe.note: Christian woman in Corinth whose household reported divisions to Paul (1 Corinthians 1:11).

Chuza.note: Steward of Herod Antipas; his wife Joanna supported Jesus (Luke 8:3).

Cis.note: Alternative form of Kish, father of Saul (Acts 13:21).

Claudia.note: Christian woman greeted in Paul’s second letter to Timothy (2 Timothy 4:21).

Clement.note: Believer in Philippi commended by Paul (Philippians 4:3).

Cleophas.note: Possibly the same as Clopas; met the risen Jesus on the road to Emmaus (Luke 24:18).

Coniah.note: Another name for Jehoiachin, exiled king of Judah (Jeremiah 22:24).

Cornelius.note: Roman centurion who received the Holy Spirit; first Gentile convert (Acts 10).

Cosam.note: Ancestor of Jesus listed in Luke’s genealogy (Luke 3:28).

Coz.note: Ancestor of priestly families; descendant of Judah (1 Chronicles 4:8).

Cozbi.note: Midianite woman slain by Phinehas for leading Israel into sin (Numbers 25:14–15).

Crescens.note: Companion of Paul mentioned in his final letter (2 Timothy 4:10).

Crispus.note: Ruler of the synagogue in Corinth who believed in Jesus (Acts 18:8).

Cush.note: Son of Ham; father of Nimrod; ancestor of Cushites (Genesis 10:6–8).

Cyrenius.note: Roman governor of Syria during Jesus' birth (Luke 2:2).

Cyrus.note: Persian king who allowed Jews to return and rebuild Jerusalem (Ezra 1:1–4).

Dalaiah.note: Ancestor of Shemaiah, listed among temple servants (1 Chronicles 3:24).

Dalphon.note: One of the ten sons of Haman killed by the Jews (Esther 9:7).

Damaris.note: A woman in Athens who believed Paul's preaching (Acts 17:34).

Dan.note: Fifth son of Jacob; founder of the tribe of Dan (Genesis 30:6).

Darda.note: Wise man mentioned alongside others in Solomon’s time (1 Kings 4:31).

Darius.note: King of Persia during the time of Daniel and temple rebuilding (Daniel 6; Ezra 6:1–15).

Darkon.note: Ancestor of temple servants who returned from exile (Ezra 2:56).

Dathan.note: Rebelled against Moses and was swallowed by the earth (Numbers 16:1–32).

David.note: Second king of Israel; man after God’s own heart; author of Psalms (1 Samuel 16 – 1 Kings 2).

Dekar.note: Officer under King Solomon who provided supplies (1 Kings 4:9).

Delilah.note: Woman who betrayed Samson to the Philistines (Judges 16:4–21).

Demas.note: Companion of Paul who later deserted him (2 Timothy 4:10).

Demetrius.note: Silversmith who opposed Paul (Acts 19:24) and a well-spoken believer (3 John 1:12).

Deuel.note: Father of Eliasaph, leader of the tribe of Gad (Numbers 1:14).

Diblaim.note: Father of Gomer, the wife of Hosea (Hosea 1:3).

Dibri.note: Israelite whose daughter was involved in a blasphemy case (Leviticus 24:11).

Didymus.note: Another name for Thomas, one of the twelve apostles (John 11:16).

Diklah.note: Son of Joktan; ancestor of an Arabian tribe (Genesis 10:27).

Dinah.note: Daughter of Jacob and Leah; involved in a tragic incident at Shechem (Genesis 34).

Dionysius.note: A member of the Areopagus in Athens who believed in Christ (Acts 17:34).

Dishan.note: Son of Seir the Horite, chief of Edomite clan (Genesis 36:21).

Dishon.note: Also a son of Seir and leader of Horite clan (Genesis 36:21).

Dodavah.note: Father of Eliezer, who prophesied against Jehoshaphat (2 Chronicles 20:37).

Dodo.note: Father of Eleazar, one of David’s mighty warriors (2 Samuel 23:9).

Doeg.note: Edomite who betrayed Ahimelech and killed the priests (1 Samuel 22:9–18).

Dorcas.note: A woman known for her acts of charity, raised from the dead by Peter (Acts 9:36–42).

Drusilla.note: Wife of Felix, the Roman governor, mentioned in Acts 24:24.

Ebal.note: Mount in Israel where the blessings and curses were proclaimed (Deuteronomy 27:4–13).

Ebed.note: Servant of King David, involved in the rebellion of Adonijah (1 Kings 1:8).

Eber.note: Ancestor of several nations, including the Hebrews (Genesis 10:21–25).

Ebiasaph.note: Son of Korah and a member of the Levitical clan (1 Chronicles 6:37).

Eder.note: One of the three sons of Mushi. One of the sons of the Levites after the house of their fathers. (1 Chronicles 23:23).

Eglah.note: One of King David’s wives (2 Samuel 3:5).

Eglon.note: King of Moab who oppressed Israel before being defeated by Ehud (Judges 3:12–30).

Ehud.note: Left-handed judge of Israel who defeated King Eglon (Judges 3:12–30).

Eker.note: A man whose descendants were involved in the return from exile (Ezra 2:46).

Eladah.note: Father of Shephatiah, a warrior under King David (1 Chronicles 12:5).

Elah.note: King of Israel who was murdered by Zimri (1 Kings 16:8–10).

Elam.note: An ancient kingdom east of Israel, often associated with the Persians (Genesis 10:22).

Elasah.note: Son of Shaphan, mentioned in connection with the exiles (Jeremiah 29:3).

Eldaah.note: One of the sons of Jehoshaphat, king of Judah (2 Chronicles 21:2).

Eldad.note: One of the seventy elders who helped Moses lead Israel (Numbers 11:26–30).

Elead.note: One of the men listed among the genealogies of Judah (1 Chronicles 4:18).

Eleazar.note: Son of Aaron, who succeeded his father as high priest (Exodus 6:23).

Elhanan.note: Warrior under King David who killed a giant (2 Samuel 21:19).

Eli.note: High priest who mentored Samuel and served as a judge of Israel (1 Samuel 1–4).

Eliab.note: Brother of David who was rejected by God as king (1 Samuel 16:6–13).

Eliada.note: One of King David’s sons, a mighty warrior (1 Chronicles 14:7).

Eliahba.note: Son of David, mentioned in the genealogies (1 Chronicles 3:24).

Eliakim.note: Son of Hilkiah, appointed by Pharaoh Necho as king of Judah (2 Kings 23:34–35).

Eliam.note: Father of Bathsheba and a mighty warrior under David (2 Samuel 11:3).

Elias.note: Greek name for the prophet Elijah (Matthew 17:3).

Eliasaph.note: Son of Laadan, a leader of the Gershonites (Numbers 3:24).

Eliashib.note: High priest who helped rebuild the walls of Jerusalem (Nehemiah 3:1).

Eliathah.note: One of the sons of David, mentioned in genealogies (1 Chronicles 3:24).

Elidad.note: A leader of the tribe of Gad who helped during the census (Numbers 1:14).

Eliel.note: One of David’s mighty warriors (1 Chronicles 11:46).

Elienai.note: A member of the tribe of Ephraim who served as a leader during David’s reign (1 Chronicles 27:14).

Elihu.note: A friend of Job who spoke about God’s justice and sovereignty (Job 32–37).

Elika.note: Leader of the tribe of Manasseh during the return from exile (1 Chronicles 5:24).

Elimelech.note: Husband of Naomi and father of Mahlon and Chilion (Ruth 1:1–2).

Eliphal.note: Father of two warriors who supported King David (1 Chronicles 11:35).

Elisabeth.note: Mother of John the Baptist, wife of Zechariah (Luke 1:5–25).

Elishah.note: One of the sons of Javan, an ancestor of the Greeks (Genesis 10:4).

Elishama.note: Son of Ammihud and one of the princes of Israel during the wilderness journey (Numbers 1:10).

Elishaphat.note: Leader of a family group in Israel (1 Chronicles 3:22).

Elisheba.note: Wife of Aaron and mother of his sons (Exodus 6:23).

Elishua.note: Son of David and one of his sons (2 Samuel 5:15).

Eliud.note: One of the ancestors of Jesus (Matthew 1:14).

Elizur.note: Leader of the tribe of Reuben (Numbers 1:5).

Elmodam.note: Ancestor of Jesus in the genealogy provided in Luke (Luke 3:28).

Elnaam.note: One of the men who returned with Ezra from exile (Ezra 8:13).

Elzabad.note: A leader of the tribe of Judah during David’s reign (1 Chronicles 12:10).

Elzaphan.note: A Levite who helped in the census and the transporting of the ark (Numbers 3:30).

Emmor.note: One of the descendants of Seir the Horite (Genesis 36:23).

Eran.note: Leader of the tribe of Reuben during the census (Numbers 26:5).

Erastus.note: One of Paul’s companions and city treasurer of Corinth (Romans 16:23; 2 Timothy 4:20).

Esaias.note: Greek form of Isaiah, the prophet who foretold the coming of the Messiah (Matthew 3:3; Isaiah 40:3).

Esek.note: Location of one of the wells dug by Isaac (Genesis 26:19–22).

Eshcol.note: One of the men who, with Caleb, brought back a cluster of grapes from Canaan (Numbers 13:23).

Esrom.note: Ancestor of Jesus through the line of Judah (Matthew 1:3; Luke 3:33).

Esther.note: Jewish queen of Persia who saved her people from Haman’s plot (Book of Esther).

Ethbaal.note: King of Sidon and father of Jezebel (1 Kings 16:31).

Ethnan.note: Ancestor of a Levite, mentioned in genealogies (1 Chronicles 6:41).

Ethni.note: A leader of the Levites under King David (1 Chronicles 6:42).

Eubulus.note: Christian mentioned in Paul’s letter to Timothy (2 Timothy 4:21).

Evi.note: One of the kings defeated by Israel during their conquest (Numbers 21:23–24).

Ezer.note: A leader of the tribe of Asher (1 Chronicles 7:25).

Gaal.note: Leader who rebelled against Abimelech in the book of Judges (Judges 9:26–41).

Gabbai.note: One of the men who helped repair the wall of Jerusalem (Nehemiah 3:24).

Galal.note: One of the Levites who assisted in the transportation of the ark (1 Chronicles 15:17).

Gamul.note: Ancestor of a priestly family, mentioned in the genealogies (1 Chronicles 5:30).

Gareb.note: One of David’s mighty men (2 Samuel 23:37).

Gatam.note: Father of a family of Judah who returned from exile (Nehemiah 7:11).

Gazez.note: A man mentioned among the leaders of the returned exiles (Nehemiah 7:56).

Gazzam.note: Ancestor of a family of temple servants (Ezra 2:45).

Geber.note: Father of a man who helped build the temple (1 Kings 5:14).

Gedaliah.note: Appointed governor of Judah after the exile (2 Kings 25:22; Jeremiah 40:5).

Gehazi.note: Servant of Elisha, struck with leprosy for lying to the prophet (2 Kings 4:27–27:9).

Gemalli.note: Father of the high priest who was involved in the rebuilding of the temple (Nehemiah 12:14).

Gemariah.note: A son of Shaphan, a scribe in the time of King Jehoiakim, who opposed the burning of Jeremiah’s scroll (Jeremiah 36:10).

Genubath.note: Son of Hadad the Edomite and raised in Pharaoh’s household in Egypt (1 Kings 11:20).

Gera.note: A Benjaminite ancestor of Ehud, the left-handed judge of Israel (Judges 3:15).

Geuel.note: A spy from the tribe of Gad who gave a discouraging report of the land of Canaan (Numbers 13:15).

Gibbar.note: One of the leaders whose descendants returned from exile with Zerubbabel (Ezra 2:20).

Giddel.note: A family of temple servants who returned from Babylonian exile (Ezra 2:47).

Gideon.note: A judge of Israel who defeated the Midianites with 300 men (Judges 6–8).

Gideoni.note: Father of Abidan, leader of the tribe of Benjamin during the wilderness journey (Numbers 1:11).

Gilalai.note: A musician who participated in the dedication of the wall of Jerusalem (Nehemiah 12:36).

Ginath.note: Father of Tibni, a rival to Omri for the throne of Israel (1 Kings 16:21).

Gispa.note: An overseer in post-exilic Jerusalem, likely a Levite or temple servant (Nehemiah 11:21).

Goliath.note: A giant Philistine warrior defeated by David with a sling and a stone (1 Samuel 17).

Gomer.note: The unfaithful wife of the prophet Hosea, used symbolically to represent Israel (Hosea 1:3).

Guni.note: A son of Naphtali, patriarch of the Gunites (Genesis 46:24).

Haahashtari.note: A descendant of Caleb listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 4:6).

Habaiah.note: A priestly family that returned from exile but was excluded due to lack of genealogical proof (Ezra 2:61).

Hachaliah.note: Father of Nehemiah, who led the rebuilding of Jerusalem's walls (Nehemiah 1:1).

Hachmoni.note: Father of Jehiel, an instructor in the royal household (1 Chronicles 27:32).

Hadad.note: A royal name among Edomites; also a pagan storm god (Genesis 36:35; 1 Kings 11:14).

Hadadezer.note: King of Zobah defeated by David in battle (2 Samuel 8:3).

Hadar.note: A chief of Edom mentioned in the genealogy of Esau (Genesis 36:39).

Hadassah.note: Hebrew name of Queen Esther before she became queen of Persia (Esther 2:7).

Hadlai.note: Father of Amasa, a leader in Ephraim during King Ahaz’s reign (2 Chronicles 28:12).

Hadoram.note: Overseer of tribute under King David; possibly also a son of Joktan (2 Samuel 8:10; Genesis 10:27).

Hagab.note: A temple servant listed among those returning from exile (Ezra 2:46).

Hagar.note: An Egyptian servant of Sarah and the mother of Ishmael (Genesis 16:1–15).

Haggeri.note: Father of one of David’s mighty men (1 Chronicles 11:38).

Haggiah.note: A descendant of Levi mentioned in the genealogies (1 Chronicles 6:30).

Haggith.note: One of King David’s wives and the mother of Adonijah (2 Samuel 3:4).

Hakkatan.note: Ancestor of Johanan, one of those returning from exile (Ezra 8:12).

Hakkoz.note: A priestly family that returned from exile and served in the temple (Ezra 2:61).

Hakupha.note: A family of temple servants who returned from exile (Ezra 2:51).

Ham.note: One of Noah’s sons and the father of Canaan, Cush, Mizraim, and Put (Genesis 10:6).

Haman.note: The Agagite official who plotted to destroy the Jews in Persia (Esther 3:1–6).

Hamor.note: Father of Shechem, who sought to marry Dinah (Genesis 34:2–8).

Hamul.note: A grandson of Judah born in Egypt (Genesis 46:12).

Hamutal.note: Mother of kings Jehoahaz and Zedekiah (2 Kings 23:31; 24:18).

Hanameel.note: Cousin of the prophet Jeremiah who sold him a field in Anathoth (Jeremiah 32:7).

Hanan.note: A common name; several men including a temple official and a returned exile (Nehemiah 8:7).

Hananiah.note: A name shared by several figures, including a false prophet (Jeremiah 28:1) and a friend of Daniel (Daniel 1:6–7).

Haniel.note: A leader of the tribe of Manasseh during the division of the land (Numbers 34:23).

Hannah.note: Mother of the prophet Samuel, known for her prayer and dedication (1 Samuel 1:10–28).

Hanniel.note: A leader from the tribe of Ephraim appointed to divide the land (Numbers 34:23).

Hanoch.note: A son of Reuben and father of the Hanochite clan (Genesis 46:9).

Hanun.note: Son of Nahash, who mistreated David’s envoys and brought war (2 Samuel 10:1–4).

Haran.note: Brother of Abraham and father of Lot (Genesis 11:26–2).

Harbonah.note: A eunuch of King Xerxes who suggested Haman be hanged on his own gallows (Esther 7:9).

Hareph.note: A descendant of Caleb who founded Beth-zur (1 Chronicles 2:51).

Harhaiah.note: A man who helped repair Jerusalem's walls during Nehemiah’s leadership (Nehemiah 3:8).

Harhas.note: Grandfather of Shallum, who was married to Huldah the prophetess (2 Kings 22:14).

Harhur.note: A family of temple servants who returned from the Babylonian exile (Ezra 2:51).

Harim.note: Name of both a priestly family and a temple-servant clan returning from exile (Ezra 2:32, 39).

Harnepher.note: A descendant of Manasseh listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 7:36).

Harsha.note: A family of temple servants who returned from exile (Ezra 2:52).

Harum.note: A descendant of Judah mentioned in the genealogies (1 Chronicles 4:8).

Harumaph.note: A man who helped repair the wall of Jerusalem (Nehemiah 3:10).

Haruz.note: Father of Meshullemeth, the queen mother of King Amon (2 Kings 21:19).

Hasadiah.note: A descendant of Zerubbabel listed in the post-exilic genealogy (1 Chronicles 3:20).

Hashabiah.note: A Levite leader and overseer of temple service (1 Chronicles 9:14; Nehemiah 11:15).

Hashabnah.note: A man who sealed the covenant with Nehemiah (Nehemiah 10:25).

Hashem.note: A mighty warrior of David listed among his elite men (1 Chronicles 11:34).

Hashub.note: A man who helped with the rebuilding of Jerusalem’s walls (Nehemiah 3:11).

Hashubah.note: A descendant of David listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 3:20).

Hashum.note: A leader among the returning exiles (Ezra 2:19; Nehemiah 10:18).

Hashupha.note: A family of temple servants who returned from exile (Ezra 2:43).

Hasrah.note: Father of Shallum, the keeper of the royal wardrobe (2 Chronicles 34:22).

Hatach.note: A eunuch of King Ahasuerus who served as a messenger for Queen Esther (Esther 4:5–10).

Hathath.note: A descendant of Othniel from the tribe of Judah (1 Chronicles 4:13).

Hatita.note: One of the gatekeeper families returning from exile (Ezra 2:42).

Hattil.note: A family of temple servants who returned from exile (Ezra 2:57).

Hattush.note: A priestly descendant of David and one of the returnees from exile (Ezra 8:2; 1 Chronicles 3:22).

Hazael.note: King of Aram who oppressed Israel during the reign of Jehu (2 Kings 8:12–15).

Hazaiah.note: A descendant of Judah who lived in Jerusalem after the exile (Nehemiah 11:5).

Hazelel.note: A descendant of Judah, mentioned in genealogies (1 Chronicles 4:23).

Hazelelponi.note: A woman in the tribe of Judah, mentioned in genealogies (1 Chronicles 4:3).

Hazo.note: Son of Nahor and Milcah, Abraham’s brother and sister-in-law (Genesis 22:22).

Heber.note: Several individuals; notably, Heber the Kenite, whose wife Jael killed Sisera (Judges 4:17).

Hegai.note: A eunuch in charge of the women in King Xerxes’ harem, who helped Esther (Esther 2:8–15).

Heldai.note: One of the men who brought silver and gold for the crown in Zechariah’s vision (Zechariah 6:10).

Helek.note: A son of Gilead and a clan leader in the tribe of Manasseh (Numbers 26:30).

Helem.note: A descendant of Asher and father of daughters (1 Chronicles 7:35).

Helez.note: One of David’s mighty warriors from the tribe of Ephraim (2 Samuel 23:26).

Heli.note: Father of Mary, the mother of Jesus, in the genealogy of Jesus (Luke 3:23).

Helkai.note: A priest during the time of Joiakim (Nehemiah 12:15).

Hemda.note: A member of the family of David in the genealogies (1 Chronicles 3:24).

Hesed.note: A man in the genealogy of Judah (1 Chronicles 4:22).

Hoshea.note: Last king of Israel, during the Assyrian conquest (2 Kings 17:1–6).

Helon.note: Father of Eliab, the leader of the tribe of Zebulun during the census (Numbers 1:9).

Heman.note: One of the wise men in King Solomon’s court, noted for his wisdom (1 Kings 4:31).

Hemam.note: A musician and son of Joel, mentioned in the genealogies (1 Chronicles 6:33).

Hen.note: Possibly a symbolic name meaning “grace” or “favor” (Zechariah 6:14).

Henadad.note: Ancestor of Levites who helped rebuild the temple and walls (Ezra 3:9; Nehemiah 3:24).

Henoch.note: Another form of “Enoch,” son of Cain or a son of Reuben (Genesis 4:17; 46:9).

Hepher.note: Ancestor of the Hepherites, mentioned in the genealogies of the tribe of Manasseh (Joshua 17:2).

Heresh.note: A descendant of Machir, son of Manasseh (1 Chronicles 7:16).

Hermas.note: A Christian greeted by Paul in his letter to the Romans (Romans 16:14).

Hermogenes.note: A man who turned away from Paul while he was imprisoned (2 Timothy 1:15).

Herod.note: King of Judea during the time of Jesus' birth (Matthew 2:1–19).

Herodion.note: A Jewish Christian greeted by Paul as a kinsman (Romans 16:11).

Hezekiah.note: King of Judah, known for his faithfulness and for his reforms (2 Kings 18–20).

Hezrai.note: One of David’s mighty warriors, also called Hezro (2 Samuel 23:35).

Hezron.note: Son of Perez and ancestor of Jesus (Matthew 1:3; Luke 3:33).

Hiddai.note: One of David’s mighty men, also called Hurai (2 Samuel 23:30).

Hiel.note: Rebuilt Jericho and fulfilled a curse by losing his sons (1 Kings 16:34).

Hilkiah.note: High priest who discovered the book of the law during King Josiah’s reign (2 Kings 22:8).

Hillel.note: Famous Jewish teacher in the first century B.C., often cited in the Gospels (Matthew 5:44).

Hirah.note: A friend of Judah and an Adullamite (Genesis 38:1, 12).

Hiram.note: King of Tyre who assisted King Solomon in building the temple (1 Kings 5:1–12).

Hizkijah.note: A variation of Hezekiah; a returned exile who signed the covenant (Nehemiah 10:17).

Hobab.note: Brother-in-law or father-in-law of Moses; guided Israel in the wilderness (Numbers 10:29).

Hod.note: A descendant of Judah listed in the genealogies (1 Chronicles 4:1).

Hodaiah.note: A name shared by several post-exilic leaders and Levites (Nehemiah 8:7; 10:10).

Hodesh.note: One of the wives of Shaharaim, a Benjamite (1 Chronicles 8:9).

Hoglah.note: One of the five daughters of Zelophehad who requested land inheritance (Numbers 27:1–7).

Hoham.note: King of Hebron defeated by Joshua (Joshua 10:3).

Homam.note: A descendant of Esau listed in the genealogy of Edom (1 Chronicles 1:39).

Hophni.note: Son of Eli the priest; judged for his corruption (1 Samuel 2:34).

Horam.note: King of Gezer who opposed Joshua and was defeated (Joshua 10:33).

Hori.note: A son of Simeon and father of Shaphat, one of the twelve spies (Genesis 46:10; Numbers 13:8).

Hosah.note: A gatekeeper from the tribe of Merari (1 Chronicles 16:38).

Hoshaiah.note: Father of Jezaniah, a military leader after the exile (Jeremiah 42:1).

Hoshama.note: A descendant of Jeconiah listed in the royal line (1 Chronicles 3:18).

Hotham.note: A warrior from the tribe of Asher (1 Chronicles 7:32).

Hothir.note: Son of Heman, appointed to temple music ministry (1 Chronicles 25:4).

Hul.note: A son of Aram and grandson of Shem (Genesis 10:23).

Hupham.note: A descendant of Benjamin listed in genealogies (Numbers 26:39).

Huppim.note: A son of Benjamin and founder of the Huppimites (Genesis 46:21).

Hur.note: A companion of Moses and Aaron who helped hold up Moses’ hands during battle (Exodus 17:10–12).

Huram.note: King of Tyre or skilled artisan sent to help Solomon (2 Chronicles 2:13; 1 Kings 7:13–14).

Huri.note: A clan leader in the tribe of Gad (1 Chronicles 5:14).

Husham.note: A king of Edom who reigned before David (Genesis 36:37).

Hushathite.note: A term used to describe a member of the Hushah family (1 Chronicles 11:34).

Hushim.note: A son of Dan, mentioned in genealogies (Genesis 46:23).

Hushah.note: A descendant of Judah listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 4:4).

Hushai.note: A friend of King David who helped him during the rebellion of Absalom (2 Samuel 15:32).

Hymeneus.note: A heretical teacher mentioned by Paul as having shipwrecked his faith (1 Timothy 1:20).

Ibhar.note: One of King David’s sons born in Jerusalem (2 Samuel 5:15).

Ibneiah.note: A leader of the tribe of Benjamin who lived in Jerusalem after the exile (1 Chronicles 9:8).

Ibri.note: A Levite of the family of Merari (1 Chronicles 24:27).

Ibzan.note: A judge of Israel from Bethlehem who had 30 sons and 30 daughters (Judges 12:8–10).

Igdaliah.note: A man described as 'of the Lord,' father of the prophet Zephaniah (Jeremiah 35:4, possibly related).

Igeal.note: A spy from the tribe of Issachar sent to explore Canaan (Numbers 13:7).

Ikkesh.note: Father of Ira the Tekoite, one of David’s mighty men (2 Samuel 23:26).

Imlah.note: Father of Micaiah, the prophet who foretold Ahab’s death (1 Kings 22:8).

Immer.note: A priestly family, some of whom returned from exile (Ezra 2:37).

Imnah.note: A Levite who helped distribute temple goods in the time of Hezekiah (2 Chronicles 31:14).

Imrah.note: A descendant of Asher listed among the tribal genealogies (1 Chronicles 7:36).

Imri.note: A forefather of certain gatekeepers and residents of Jerusalem (1 Chronicles 9:4; Nehemiah 3:2).

Iphedeiah.note: A descendant of Benjamin listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 8:25).

Ir.note: A descendant of Benjamin and ancestor of Shuppim and Huppim (1 Chronicles 7:12).

Ira.note: Several men named Ira; one was David’s priest, another a mighty warrior (2 Samuel 20:26; 2 Samuel 23:26).

Irad.note: A descendant of Cain listed in the genealogies of Genesis (Genesis 4:18).

Iram.note: A chief of Edom mentioned in the genealogy of Esau (Genesis 36:43).

Iri.note: A son of Bela, a leader among the Benjamites (1 Chronicles 7:7).

Irijah.note: A captain who arrested the prophet Jeremiah, accusing him of defecting to the Babylonians (Jeremiah 37:13).

Isaac.note: Son of Abraham and Sarah; father of Jacob and Esau (Genesis 21:3; Hebrews 11:20).

Iscah.note: Niece of Abraham, daughter of Haran (Genesis 11:29).

Ishbak.note: One of the sons of Abraham by Keturah (Genesis 25:2).

Ishi.note: Several men named Ishi appear in tribal lists; one was from Simeon (1 Chronicles 4:42).

Ishiah.note: A Levite listed among the descendants of Merari (1 Chronicles 24:30).

Ishmael.note: Son of Abraham and Hagar; ancestor of the Ishmaelites (Genesis 16:11–12).

Ishmaiah.note: A Gibeonite chief and mighty man in David’s army (1 Chronicles 12:4).

Ishmerai.note: A descendant of Benjamin listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 8:18).

Israel.note: Name given to Jacob after wrestling with God; also used for the nation (Genesis 32:28).

Issachar.note: Ninth son of Jacob and founder of the tribe of Issachar (Genesis 30:18).

Ithai.note: A loyal warrior who supported David during Absalom’s rebellion (2 Samuel 15:19–21).

Ithamar.note: Son of Aaron who served as priest (Exodus 6:23).

Ithiel.note: Possibly a wise man or teacher referenced in Proverbs (Proverbs 30:1).

Ithmah.note: A Moabite warrior among David’s mighty men (1 Chronicles 11:46).

Ithran.note: A son of Dishon, a Horite chief (Genesis 36:26).

Ithream.note: One of David’s sons born in Hebron (2 Samuel 3:5).

Izehar.note: A son of Kohath and ancestor of Korah (Exodus 6:18).

Izrahiah.note: A chief of the tribe of Issachar and father of Michael, Obadiah, Joel, and Isshiah (1 Chronicles 7:3).

Izri.note: A leader of the temple musicians from the family of Merari (1 Chronicles 25:11).

Izhar.note: A son of Kohath and father of Korah, Nepheg, and Zichri (Exodus 6:21).

Izharite.note: A descendant or member of the family of Izhar, son of Kohath (Numbers 3:27).

Jaakan.note: A descendant of Seir the Horite; also called Akan (Genesis 36:27; 1 Chronicles 1:42).

Jaakobah.note: A descendant of Simeon listed among the tribal chiefs (1 Chronicles 4:36).

Jaala.note: The head of a family of temple servants who returned from exile (Nehemiah 7:58).

Jaalam.note: A son of Esau and his wife Oholibamah; a chief of Edom (Genesis 36:5, 18).

Jaanai.note: A leader of the tribe of Gad listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 5:12).

Jaasau.note: One of the Israelites who had married foreign wives and pledged to put them away (Ezra 10:37).

Jaasiel.note: A Gadite warrior who joined David's band in the wilderness (1 Chronicles 12:5).

Jabesh.note: Father of King Shallum of Israel (2 Kings 15:10).

Jachin.note: A priestly family; also the name of one of the two bronze pillars in Solomon's temple (1 Chronicles 24:17; 1 Kings 7:21).

Jahdai.note: A descendant of Caleb listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 2:47).

Jahzerah.note: A descendant of Benjamin listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 9:12).

Jakan.note: A descendant of Seir the Horite; also called Akan (Genesis 36:27; 1 Chronicles 1:42).

Jakeh.note: The father of Agur, the author of Proverbs 30 (Proverbs 30:1).

Jannes.note: One of the Egyptian magicians who opposed Moses; mentioned in the New Testament (2 Timothy 3:8).

Jarha.note: An Egyptian servant who married a daughter of Sheshan and became part of the tribe of Judah (1 Chronicles 2:34–35).

Jaroah.note: A descendant of Benjamin listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 8:27).

Jashen.note: Father of one of David's mighty warriors (2 Samuel 23:32).

Jashubite.note: A descendant of Jashub, son of Issachar (Numbers 26:24).

Jebus.note: An ancient name for Jerusalem before its conquest by David (Judges 19:10).

Jebusi.note: Another term for the Jebusites, the inhabitants of Jebus/Jerusalem (Joshua 18:28).

Jedi.note: A descendant of Benjamin listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 8:31).

Jehdeiah.note: An overseer of the royal flocks during King David's reign (1 Chronicles 27:30).

Jehezekel.note: A priest listed among those who returned from exile with Zerubbabel (Nehemiah 10:20).

Jehiah.note: A Levite who served as a doorkeeper for the Ark of the Covenant (1 Chronicles 15:24).

Jehizkiah.note: A leader of Ephraim who opposed the idolatry during Hezekiah's reign (2 Chronicles 29:13).

Jehoaddan.note: Wife of King Joash and mother of King Amaziah of Judah (2 Kings 14:2).

Jehoram.note: Name of two kings: Jehoram of Israel, son of Ahab (2 Kings 3:1), and Jehoram of Judah, son of Jehoshaphat (2 Chronicles 21:1).

Jehoshabeath.note: Daughter of King Jehoram of Judah who saved her nephew Joash from being killed by Athaliah (2 Chronicles 22:11).

Jehosheba.note: Daughter of King Jehoram of Judah who rescued her nephew Joash from Athaliah's massacre (2 Kings 11:2).

Jehoshua.note: Another form of the name Joshua; leader of Israel after Moses (Numbers 13:16).

Jehozabad.note: A servant of King Joash who conspired to assassinate him (2 Kings 12:21).

Jehozadak.note: Son of the high priest Seraiah; taken into exile by Nebuchadnezzar (1 Chronicles 6:15).

Jehubbah.note: A descendant of Asher listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 7:34).

Jehucal.note: A court official sent by King Zedekiah to Jeremiah to inquire of the Lord (Jeremiah 37:3).

Jehudi.note: A court official who read Jeremiah's scroll to King Jehoiakim (Jeremiah 36:14–21).

Jehudijah.note: A woman mentioned in the genealogy of Judah; mother of Jered, Heber, and Jekuthiel (1 Chronicles 4:18).

Jehush.note: A son of Eshek, a descendant of Saul (1 Chronicles 8:39).

Jekameam.note: A Levite appointed over the treasuries of the house of God (1 Chronicles 26:23).

Jekamiah.note: A descendant of David listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 3:18).

Jekuthiel.note: Son of Jehudijah; mentioned in the genealogy of Judah (1 Chronicles 4:18).

Jephunneh.note: Father of Caleb, one of the twelve spies sent to Canaan (Numbers 13:6).

Jerah.note: A son of Joktan; his descendants are associated with Arabian tribes (Genesis 10:26–27).

Jerahmeel.note: Eldest son of Hezron and ancestor of the Jerahmeelites (1 Chronicles 2:9).

Jerahmeelites.note: A clan descended from Jerahmeel, inhabiting the Negev region (1 Samuel 27:10).

Jeremoth.note: A Levite musician appointed by David for temple service (1 Chronicles 25:22).

Jeriah.note: A Levite, head of the family of Hebronites during David's reign (1 Chronicles 23:19).

Jeriel.note: A chief of the tribe of Issachar listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 7:2).

Jerijah.note: A Levite, head of the Hebronites during King David's reign (1 Chronicles 23:19).

Jerimoth.note: A son of King David, listed among his sons in 1 Chronicles 3:1–8.

Jerioth.note: A wife of Caleb, mentioned in genealogies (1 Chronicles 2:18).

Jeroham.note: Father of Elkanah and grandfather of the prophet Samuel (1 Samuel 1:1).

Jerusha.note: Daughter of Zadok and mother of King Jotham of Judah (2 Kings 15:33).

Jeshaiah.note: A Levite who returned from exile with Ezra (Ezra 8:7).

Jeshebeab.note: A priest in charge of the twelfth division of service in the temple (1 Chronicles 24:13).

Jesher.note: A son of Caleb, mentioned in genealogies (1 Chronicles 2:18).

Jeshishai.note: A Gadite leader who joined David at Ziklag (1 Chronicles 12:11).

Jeshohaia.note: A descendant of Eliezer, son of Moses (1 Chronicles 26:25).

Jeshurun.note: A poetic name for Israel, meaning 'upright one' (Deuteronomy 32:15).

Jesiah.note: A Korahite who joined David's forces at Ziklag (1 Chronicles 12:6).

Jesimiel.note: A Simeonite leader mentioned in genealogies (1 Chronicles 4:36).

Jesui.note: A son of Asher and founder of the Jesuite family (Numbers 26:44).

Jetheth.note: One of the chiefs of Edom, descendant of Esau (Genesis 36:40).

Jetur.note: A son of Ishmael; his descendants settled in the region of Arabia (Genesis 25:15).

Jeuel.note: A descendant of Zerah who lived in Jerusalem after the exile (1 Chronicles 9:6).

Jeush.note: A son of Esau and his wife Oholibamah; a chief of Edom (Genesis 36:5, 18).

Jezaniah.note: A leader among the Judean military officers after the destruction of Jerusalem (Jeremiah 42:1).

Jezer.note: A son of Naphtali and founder of the Jezerite family (Genesis 46:24).

Jeziah.note: A descendant of Merari who returned from exile (Ezra 8:19).

Jezoar.note: A son of Helah, wife of Ashur (1 Chronicles 4:7).

Jezrahiah.note: Leader of the singers in the dedication of the wall of Jerusalem (Nehemiah 12:42).

Jibsam.note: A descendant of Tola, son of Issachar (1 Chronicles 7:2).

Jidlaph.note: A son of Nahor, Abraham's brother (Genesis 22:22).

Jimnah.note: A son of Asher and founder of the Jimnite family (Genesis 46:17).

Joab.note: Son of Zeruiah and commander of King David's army (2 Samuel 2:13).

Joah.note: A recorder during the reign of King Hezekiah (2 Kings 18:18).

Joahaz.note: Also known as Ahaziah; king of Judah and son of Jehoram (2 Chronicles 21:17).

Jobab.note: A descendant of Esau and one of the early kings of Edom (Genesis 36:33).

Joed.note: Father of Maaseiah, who helped rebuild Jerusalem’s wall (Nehemiah 3:6).

Joezer.note: One of David’s mighty men from the Korahites (1 Chronicles 12:6).

Jogli.note: Father of Bukki, a leader from the tribe of Dan (Numbers 34:22).

Joha.note: One of David’s mighty men from the tribe of Benjamin (1 Chronicles 11:26).

Johanan.note: A post-exilic leader who advised Jeremiah after Jerusalem’s fall (Jeremiah 40:8).

Joiada.note: A priest during the time of Nehemiah who helped rebuild the walls of Jerusalem (Nehemiah 3:6).

Joiarib.note: A priestly family that returned from exile with Zerubbabel (Nehemiah 11:10).

Joktan.note: Son of Eber and ancestor of several Arabian tribes (Genesis 10:25).

Jokshan.note: Son of Abraham and Keturah; father of Sheba and Dedan (Genesis 25:2–3).

Jonan.note: An ancestor of Jesus listed in Luke’s genealogy (Luke 3:30).

Jonas.note: New Testament spelling of Jonah, used by Jesus when referencing the prophet (Matthew 12:39).

Jorah.note: One of the leaders who returned with Zerubbabel from exile (Ezra 2:18).

Jorai.note: A leader from the tribe of Gad who lived in Bashan (1 Chronicles 5:13).

Joram.note: Son of Ahab and king of Israel; also a name for Jehoram of Judah (2 Kings 3:1).

Jorim.note: An ancestor of Jesus mentioned in Luke's genealogy (Luke 3:29).

Jose.note: A shortened form of Joseph in the New Testament (Luke 3:29).

Joses.note: A brother of Jesus mentioned in the New Testament (Mark 6:3).

Joshah.note: A descendant of Simeon listed in tribal genealogies (1 Chronicles 4:34).

Joshaphat.note: A Mithnite and one of David’s warriors (1 Chronicles 11:43).

Joshaviah.note: A descendant of Elnaam, listed among David’s mighty men (1 Chronicles 11:46).

Joshbekashah.note: A Levite musician in David's temple service (1 Chronicles 25:4).

Josibiah.note: Father of Jehu, one of the leaders of the tribe of Simeon (1 Chronicles 4:35).

Josiphiah.note: Ancestor of a family returning from Babylon with Ezra (Ezra 8:10).

Jozabad.note: A Levite who helped with the distribution of temple offerings (2 Chronicles 31:13).

Jozachar.note: A servant of King Joash who conspired in his assassination (2 Kings 12:21).

Jucal.note: Also known as Jehucal, a court official under King Zedekiah (Jeremiah 37:3).

Judas.note: A common name; most notably Judas Iscariot, who betrayed Jesus (Matthew 26:14–16).

Judith.note: A wife of Esau, daughter of Beeri the Hittite (Genesis 26:34).

Julia.note: A Christian woman greeted by Paul in his letter to the Romans (Romans 16:15).

Julius.note: A Roman centurion who escorted Paul to Rome (Acts 27:1).

Junia.note: A Christian woman greeted by Paul, possibly referred to as an apostle (Romans 16:7).

Kelita.note: One of the Levites who helped interpret the law for the people under Ezra (Nehemiah 8:7).

Kenites.note: A nomadic tribe related to Moses’ in-laws, often allied with Israel (Judges 1:16).

Kenizzite.note: A clan connected to the descendants of Esau and early allies of Israel (Genesis 15:19).

King.note: Used as a title for rulers in Israel and surrounding nations; not a personal name.

Kohathites.note: Descendants of Kohath, responsible for carrying sacred items of the Tabernacle (Numbers 4:15).

Kolaiah.note: Father of Ahab, a false prophet condemned by Jeremiah (Jeremiah 29:21).

Korahites.note: Group of Levites descended from Korah, assigned temple duties (2 Chronicles 20:19).

Kore.note: A Levite who managed offerings during King Hezekiah's reign (2 Chronicles 31:14).

Koz.note: A priestly family that returned from exile (Ezra 2:61).

Lahad.note: A descendant of Judah listed among the clan of Koz (1 Chronicles 4:2).

Lehabim.note: Descendants of Mizraim (Egypt), possibly associated with Libyans (Genesis 10:13).

Leummim.note: Descendants of Dedan, son of Jokshan (Genesis 25:3).

Levite.note: Member of the tribe of Levi assigned religious duties (Numbers 1:50–53).

Levites.note: Tribe assigned to assist priests in temple duties (Deuteronomy 10:8).

Korahite.note: Descendant or clan of Korah, some of whom served as temple singers (1 Chronicles 6:22).

Libnites.note: A clan descended from Libni, a son of Gershon, part of the Levitical priesthood (Numbers 3:21).

Libyans.note: People of Libya; sometimes allies or enemies in biblical battles (2 Chronicles 12:3).

Likhi.note: A descendant of Naphtali listed in tribal genealogies (1 Chronicles 7:13).

Kolai.note: A recipient of a prophetic warning from Jeremiah against false prophets (Jeremiah 29:21).

Lecah.note: A descendant of Judah listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 4:21).

Libertine.note: Jewish freedman, part of a synagogue in Jerusalem (Acts 6:9).

Lotan.note: A descendant of Seir the Horite, chief of the land of Edom (Genesis 36:20).

Lubim.note: A North African people often allied with Egypt; possibly Libyans (2 Chronicles 12:3).

Lucius.note: A teacher or prophet in the church at Antioch (Acts 13:1; Romans 16:21).

Ludim.note: Descendants of Mizraim, possibly linked to the Libyans (Genesis 10:13).

Lydia.note: A seller of purple cloth from Thyatira and the first convert in Philippi (Acts 16:14).

Maaziah.note: A priest and head of the twenty-fourth division of temple service (1 Chronicles 24:18).

Machbanai.note: One of David’s mighty men from the tribe of Gad (1 Chronicles 12:13).

Mahalath.note: Daughter of Ishmael and wife of Esau (Genesis 28:9).

Mahli.note: A son of Merari, part of the Levitical lineage (1 Chronicles 6:19).

Mahol.note: A wise man whose sons were known for their wisdom, compared to Solomon (1 Kings 4:31).

Luhith.note: A Moabite ascent mentioned in judgment prophecies (Jeremiah 48:5).

Maachathite.note: A person from the region of Maacah, northeast of the Sea of Galilee (2 Samuel 10:6).

Maasei.note: Variant of Maaseiah; often a Levite or returnee from exile (Ezra 10:18).

Igal.note: Leader of the tribe of Issachar who went with the spies to Canaan (Numbers 13:7).

Jaazaniah.note: Several men by this name; one was rebuked by Ezekiel in a temple vision (Ezekiel 8:11).

Jaaziah.note: A Levite mentioned in the allocation of temple duties (1 Chronicles 24:26).

Jabal.note: A descendant of Cain, described as the father of those who live in tents and raise livestock (Genesis 4:20).

Jabez.note: A man noted for his prayer to God asking for blessing and expansion of his territory (1 Chronicles 4:9–10).

Jabin.note: The name of two kings of Hazor; one defeated by Joshua, the other by Deborah and Barak (Joshua 11:1; Judges 4:2).

Jachan.note: A leader from the tribe of Simeon (Numbers 26:12).

Jacob.note: Son of Isaac and Rebekah; father of the twelve tribes of Israel; later named Israel (Genesis 25:26; 32:28).

Jada.note: A descendant of Judah, son of Onam (1 Chronicles 2:28, 32).

Jadau.note: A priest listed among those who returned from exile (Nehemiah 12:19).

Jaddua.note: A high priest during the time of Darius the Persian (Nehemiah 12:22).

Jael.note: Wife of Heber the Kenite who killed Sisera by driving a tent peg through his head (Judges 4:17–21).

Jahath.note: A Levite, son of Shimei, and ancestor of a family of temple workers (1 Chronicles 23:10).

Jahaziah.note: A leader among the descendants of Pashhur who opposed Ezra's directive regarding foreign wives (Ezra 10:15).

Jahdiel.note: A leader in the tribe of Manasseh who lived in Gilead (1 Chronicles 5:24).

Jahdo.note: A descendant of Gibeon in the tribe of Benjamin (1 Chronicles 8:32).

Jahleel.note: A son of Zebulun and patriarch of the Jahleelites (Genesis 46:14).

Jahmai.note: A descendant of Issachar listed in the tribal genealogies (1 Chronicles 7:2).

Jahzeel.note: The first son of Naphtali and founder of the Jahzeelite family (Genesis 46:24).

Jair.note: A judge of Israel who led for 22 years and had 30 sons who rode 30 donkeys (Judges 10:3–5).

Jakim.note: A priest listed among the descendants of Aaron (1 Chronicles 24:12).

Jalon.note: A descendant of Judah, son of Ezrah (1 Chronicles 4:17).

Jamin.note: A son of Simeon and founder of the Jaminite family (Genesis 46:10).

Jamlech.note: A leader of the tribe of Simeon who participated in defeating the Amalekites (1 Chronicles 4:34).

Janna.note: Son of Joseph and father of Melchi in the genealogy of Jesus (Luke 3:24).

Japhia.note: King of Lachish defeated by Joshua (Joshua 10:3).

Japhlet.note: A descendant of Asher whose sons were part of the tribe's genealogy (1 Chronicles 7:32).

Jarah.note: A descendant of King Saul listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 9:42).

Jashobeam.note: One of David's chief mighty men who killed 300 men with his spear (1 Chronicles 11:11).

Jashub.note: A son of Issachar and founder of the Jashubite family (Numbers 26:24).

Jasiel.note: A warrior from the tribe of Benjamin who joined David's forces (1 Chronicles 11:47).

Jathniel.note: A Levite listed among the temple musicians (1 Chronicles 26:2).

Jaziz.note: An overseer of King David's flocks (1 Chronicles 27:31).

Jeaterai.note: A Levite listed in the genealogies of the sons of Gershom (1 Chronicles 6:21).

Jeberechiah.note: The father of Zechariah, who was a witness for the prophet Isaiah (Isaiah 8:2).

Jecamiah.note: A descendant of Jeconiah, part of the Davidic line (1 Chronicles 3:18).

Jecoliah.note: Mother of King Uzziah of Judah (2 Kings 15:2).

Jeconiah.note: King of Judah taken into Babylonian captivity; also called Jehoiachin (2 Kings 24:6).

Jedaiah.note: A common priestly name; multiple individuals including those returning from exile (Ezra 2:36).

Jediael.note: A warrior from the tribe of Benjamin who joined David's forces (1 Chronicles 12:20).

Jedidah.note: Mother of King Josiah of Judah (2 Kings 22:1).

Jedidiah.note: The name given by Nathan to Solomon, meaning 'beloved of the Lord' (2 Samuel 12:25).

Jeduthun.note: A Levite and one of the chief musicians appointed by David for temple worship (1 Chronicles 16:41–42).

Jehoahaz.note: Name of several kings: Jehoahaz of Israel, son of Jehu (2 Kings 13:1); Jehoahaz of Judah, son of Josiah (2 Kings 23:30).

Jehoash.note: Also known as Joash; king of Judah who initiated repairs to the temple (2 Kings 12:1–21).

Jehohanan.note: A priest during the time of Ezra who returned from exile (Ezra 10:28).

Jehoiachin.note: King of Judah who was taken captive to Babylon by Nebuchadnezzar (2 Kings 24:8–16).

Jehoiada.note: A high priest who led the overthrow of Queen Athaliah and crowned Joash as king (2 Kings 11:4–16).

Jehoiakim.note: King of Judah appointed by Pharaoh Neco, known for burning the scroll of Jeremiah's prophecy (Jeremiah 36:23).

Jehoiarib.note: Leader of one of the priestly divisions during King David's reign (1 Chronicles 24:7).

Jehonadab.note: Son of Rechab who assisted Jehu in exterminating Baal worshipers (2 Kings 10:15–23).

Jehonathan.note: A Levite sent by King Jehoshaphat to teach the Law in the cities of Judah (2 Chronicles 17:8).

Kadmiel.note: One of the leaders of the Levites who helped rebuild the temple after the exile (Ezra 2:40).

Kallai.note: A priest who helped rebuild the wall of Jerusalem under Nehemiah (Nehemiah 12:20).

Kareah.note: Father of Johanan, a military leader after the fall of Jerusalem (Jeremiah 40:8).

Kelaiah.note: One of those who had taken a foreign wife and was listed among the exiles (Ezra 10:23).

Kemuel.note: Prince of Ephraim during the division of Canaan (Numbers 34:24).

Kenan.note: A descendant of Seth and ancestor of Noah (Genesis 5:9–14).

Kenaz.note: Brother of Caleb and father of Othniel, Israel’s first judge (Joshua 15:17).

Keros.note: A family of temple servants who returned from exile (Ezra 2:44).

Keturah.note: Second wife of Abraham and mother of six sons (Genesis 25:1–4).

Kezia.note: Second daughter of Job born after his restoration (Job 42:14).

Kish.note: Father of King Saul and a Benjamite (1 Samuel 9:1).

Kishi.note: A Merarite Levite and father of Ethan the singer (1 Chronicles 6:44).

Kohath.note: Second son of Levi; ancestor of the Kohathite clan (Exodus 6:16).

Korah.note: A Levite who led a rebellion against Moses and was swallowed by the earth (Numbers 16:1–32).

Kushaiah.note: A Levite of the sons of Merari who helped with temple duties (1 Chronicles 15:17).

Laadah.note: A descendant of Judah, son of Shelah (1 Chronicles 4:21).

Laadan.note: A Levite in the genealogies of the Gershonites (1 Chronicles 23:7).

Laban.note: Jacob's uncle and father-in-law who tricked him into marrying both Leah and Rachel (Genesis 29:16–30).

Lael.note: A Levite ancestor from the Gershonite line (Numbers 3:24).

Lahmi.note: Brother of Goliath slain by Elhanan (1 Chronicles 20:5).

Lamech.note: Father of Noah and descendant of Seth (Genesis 5:28–29).

Lapidoth.note: Alternate spelling of Lappidoth, husband of Deborah (Judges 4:4).

Lazarus.note: Friend of Jesus whom he raised from the dead (John 11:1–44).

Leah.note: First wife of Jacob and mother of six of the tribes of Israel (Genesis 29:23).

Lebbeus.note: Another name for Thaddaeus, one of the twelve apostles (Matthew 10:3).

Lemuel.note: A king mentioned in Proverbs 31, possibly fictional or symbolic (Proverbs 31:1).

Levi.note: Third son of Jacob and founder of the Levitical priesthood (Genesis 29:34).

Libni.note: Son of Gershon and ancestor of the Libnites, a Levitical clan (Numbers 3:18).

Linus.note: A Christian greeted by Paul in his second letter to Timothy (2 Timothy 4:21).

Lois.note: Grandmother of Timothy and known for her sincere faith (2 Timothy 1:5).

Lot.note: Nephew of Abraham; escaped Sodom’s destruction (Genesis 11:27; 19:29).

Lucas.note: Another form of Luke, the physician and companion of Paul (Philemon 1:24).

Luke.note: Author of the Gospel of Luke and Acts; a physician and companion of Paul (Colossians 4:14).

Lysanias.note: A tetrarch of Abilene mentioned during the time of John the Baptist (Luke 3:1).

Lysias.note: A Roman commander who protected Paul from mob violence (Acts 21:31–33).

Lud.note: A son of Shem and ancestor of the Lydians or a Near Eastern people (Genesis 10:22).

Machi.note: Father of Gilead, a descendant of Manasseh (Numbers 26:29).

Machir.note: Son of Manasseh and father of Gilead; associated with the region east of the Jordan (Genesis 50:23; Numbers 32:39–40).

Malchiah.note: A priest or official involved in rebuilding Jerusalem’s wall (Nehemiah 3:11).

Malchus.note: Servant of the high priest whose ear was cut off by Peter at Jesus’ arrest (John 18:10).

Manaen.note: A teacher in the church at Antioch, brought up with Herod the tetrarch (Acts 13:1).

Manasseh.note: Son of Joseph; founder of one of the tribes of Israel (Genesis 41:51).

Mark.note: Author of the Gospel of Mark; companion of Paul and Peter (Acts 12:25; 1 Peter 5:13).

Martha.note: Sister of Mary and Lazarus; known for serving and hosting Jesus (Luke 10:38–42; John 11).

Mary.note: Several women in the New Testament including Jesus’ mother and Mary Magdalene (Luke 1:27; John 20:1).

Mattan.note: Father of Shephatiah, a false prophet in Jeremiah's day (Jeremiah 38:1).

Merab.note: Daughter of King Saul, originally promised to David but given to another (1 Samuel 18:19).

Meshech.note: A son of Japheth and ancestor of a people living near the Black Sea (Genesis 10:2; Ezekiel 27:13).

Meshullam.note: A common post-exilic name among priests, Levites, and leaders involved in temple rebuilding (Nehemiah 3:6; 8:4).

Michal.note: Daughter of Saul and wife of David; known for her love, then disdain toward David (1 Samuel 18:27; 2 Samuel 6:16).

Midian.note: A son of Abraham and Keturah; also the name of a nomadic tribe often in conflict with Israel (Genesis 25:2; Judges 6).

Miriam.note: Sister of Moses and Aaron, a prophetess who led Israel in song (Exodus 15:20).

Mishael.note: One of Daniel’s three companions in Babylon, also called Meshach (Daniel 1:6–7).

Moab.note: Son of Lot and founder of the Moabite people (Genesis 19:37).

Mordecai.note: A Jew in Persia who raised Esther and helped save the Jews from Haman's plot (Esther 2–10).

Nahash.note: King of the Ammonites who threatened Jabesh-gilead (1 Samuel 11:1–11).

Nahor.note: Abraham’s grandfather and also his brother (Genesis 11:22, 29).

Naphtali.note: A son of Jacob and founder of the tribe of Naphtali (Genesis 30:7–8).

Nebuchadnezzar.note: King of Babylon who conquered Judah and destroyed Jerusalem (Daniel 1:1–2; 2 Kings 24–25).

Elnathan.note: A royal official sent by King Jehoiakim to arrest the prophet Uriah (Jeremiah 26:22).

Elon.note: A judge of Israel from the tribe of Zebulun who judged for ten years (Judges 12:11–12).

Elpaal.note: A Benjaminite whose descendants built several towns (1 Chronicles 8:12).

Elpalet.note: One of David’s sons born in Jerusalem (1 Chronicles 14:5).

Elymas.note: A sorcerer who opposed Paul and was struck blind (Acts 13:8–11).

Enos.note: Son of Seth and grandson of Adam; associated with the early calling on God’s name (Genesis 4:26).

Enosh.note: Another spelling of Enos, son of Seth, marking the beginning of public worship (Genesis 4:26).

Epaphras.note: A companion of Paul and faithful servant to the church in Colossae (Colossians 1:7).

Epenetus.note: The first convert to Christ in Asia, greeted by Paul (Romans 16:5).

Ephah.note: A concubine of Caleb and also a Midianite tribe (1 Chronicles 2:46; Isaiah 60:6).

Ephraim.note: Second son of Joseph; ancestor of a powerful tribe of Israel (Genesis 41:52).

Ephron.note: A Hittite who sold Abraham the cave of Machpelah (Genesis 23:8–17).

Er.note: Firstborn son of Judah, killed by God for his wickedness (Genesis 38:7).

Esarhaddon.note: King of Assyria who resettled people in Samaria (2 Kings 19:37; Ezra 4:2).

Esau.note: Twin brother of Jacob; ancestor of the Edomites (Genesis 25:25; 36:1).

Esli.note: An ancestor of Jesus listed in His genealogy (Luke 3:25).

Ethan.note: A wise man from the tribe of Ezra; possibly the author of Psalm 89 (1 Kings 4:31).

Euodias.note: A woman in the Philippian church urged to reconcile with Syntyche (Philippians 4:2).

Eutychus.note: A young man who fell asleep and died during Paul’s sermon, then was raised back to life (Acts 20:9–10).

Eve.note: The first woman, created by God as a companion for Adam (Genesis 2:22–23; 3:20).

Ezri.note: An overseer of workers in King David’s administration (1 Chronicles 27:26).

Eliezer.note: Name of multiple men, including Abraham’s servant and a son of Moses (Genesis 15:2; Exodus 18:4).

Elioenai.note: A descendant of David listed in the post-exilic genealogies (1 Chronicles 3:23–24).

Eliphalet.note: Name shared by two sons of David listed in genealogies (2 Samuel 5:16; 1 Chronicles 3:8).

Eliphaz.note: Son of Esau and father of the Temanites; also a friend of Job (Genesis 36:4; Job 2:11).

Elkanah.note: Father of the prophet Samuel and husband of Hannah (1 Samuel 1:1–2).

Enoch.note: A descendant of Adam who walked with God and was taken to heaven without dying (Genesis 5:24).

Epaphroditus.note: A companion of Paul who brought gifts from Philippi and was commended for his service (Philippians 2:25–30).

Epher.note: A descendant of Midian, son of Abraham and Keturah (Genesis 25:4).

Eri.note: A son of Gad and ancestor of the Erites (Genesis 46:16).

Eshek.note: A descendant of Benjamin listed in tribal genealogies (1 Chronicles 8:39).

Eunice.note: Mother of Timothy, praised for her sincere faith (2 Timothy 1:5).

Ezbon.note: A son of Gad and forefather of a tribal clan (Numbers 26:16).

Felix.note: Roman governor who heard Paul's case and kept him imprisoned for two years (Acts 24:27).

Festus.note: Successor to Felix as Roman governor; heard Paul’s appeal to Caesar (Acts 25:1–12).

Fortunatus.note: A Christian who brought greetings in Paul’s letter to the Corinthians (1 Corinthians 16:17).

Gad.note: Seventh son of Jacob; ancestor of the tribe of Gad (Genesis 30:9–11).

Gaddi.note: Spy from the tribe of Manasseh who scouted Canaan (Numbers 13:11).

Gaddiel.note: Spy from the tribe of Zebulun who scouted Canaan (Numbers 13:10).

Gaius.note: A companion of Paul known for his hospitality (Romans 16:23; 3 John 1:1).

Gallio.note: Roman proconsul of Achaia who dismissed charges against Paul (Acts 18:12–17).

Gamaliel.note: A respected Pharisee who advised caution regarding the apostles (Acts 5:34–39).

Jemima.note: One of Job's three daughters born after his restoration (Job 42:14).

Jerubbaal.note: Another name for Gideon, meaning 'Let Baal contend'; he destroyed the altar of Baal (Judges 6:32).

Jerubbesheth.note: Another name for Gideon, used in 2 Samuel 11:21.

Jether.note: Father of Amasa, commander of Absalom's army (2 Samuel 17:25).

Jethro.note: Priest of Midian and father-in-law of Moses (Exodus 3:1).

Jezebel.note: Wife of King Ahab; notorious for promoting Baal worship and opposing the prophet Elijah (1 Kings 16:31).

Joanna.note: A follower of Jesus who supported his ministry and witnessed his resurrection (Luke 8:3; 24:10).

Joash.note: King of Judah who began his reign at seven years old and repaired the temple (2 Kings 12:1–21).

Job.note: A righteous man who endured great suffering and is the central figure of the Book of Job (Job 1:1).

Jochebed.note: Mother of Moses, Aaron, and Miriam, from the tribe of Levi (Exodus 6:20).

Jonadab.note: Son of Rechab, known for instituting a strict code of conduct for his descendants (Jeremiah 35:6).

Jonathan.note: Son of Saul and close friend of David, known for his bravery and loyalty (1 Samuel 18:1–4).

Joseph.note: Husband of Mary and earthly father of Jesus; also a son of Jacob who ruled Egypt (Genesis 37:3; Matthew 1:16).

Joseph of Arimathea.note: A wealthy disciple of Jesus who provided his tomb for Jesus’ burial (Matthew 27:57–60).

Joshua.note: Successor to Moses and leader of the Israelites into the Promised Land (Joshua 1:1–2).

Josiah.note: King of Judah who instituted major religious reforms and found the Book of the Law (2 Kings 22:1–20).

Jotham.note: King of Judah who succeeded his father Uzziah and did what was right in the Lord’s sight (2 Kings 15:32–34).

Jubal.note: Descendant of Cain, known as the father of all who play the harp and flute (Genesis 4:21).

Judah.note: Fourth son of Jacob and founder of the tribe of Judah; also the southern kingdom of Israel (Genesis 29:35).

Jude.note: Brother of James and author of the Epistle of Jude in the New Testament (Jude 1:1).

Justus.note: A Christian associate of Paul; several men by this name appear in the New Testament (Acts 18:7; Colossians 4:11).

Jahaziel.note: A Levite who prophesied victory to King Jehoshaphat against the Moabites and Ammonites (2 Chronicles 20:14–17).

Jambres.note: One of the Egyptian magicians who opposed Moses; mentioned in the New Testament (2 Timothy 3:8).

James.note: Several individuals: James the son of Zebedee (Matthew 4:21), James the son of Alphaeus (Matthew 10:3), and James the brother of Jesus (Galatians 1:19).

Japheth.note: One of Noah's three sons; ancestor of many nations (Genesis 5:32; 10:1).

Jared.note: Father of Enoch and a descendant of Seth (Genesis 5:18).

Jarib.note: A descendant of Levi, mentioned in the genealogies (1 Chronicles 23:10).

Jason.note: A Thessalonian who hosted Paul and Silas and was attacked by a mob (Acts 17:5–9).

Javan.note: Son of Japheth; his descendants are associated with Greece (Genesis 10:2).

Jehaleleel.note: A descendant of Judah listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 4:16).

Jehiel.note: A Levite appointed by David to oversee the treasures of the house of God (1 Chronicles 26:21).

Jehoshaphat.note: King of Judah noted for his religious reforms and alliance with Ahab (1 Kings 22:41–50).

Jehu.note: King of Israel anointed by a prophet to destroy the house of Ahab and eradicate Baal worship (2 Kings 9:1–10:36).

Jephthah.note: A judge of Israel who delivered the Israelites from the Ammonites; known for his tragic vow (Judges 11:1–40).

Jeroboam.note: The first king of the northern kingdom of Israel after the division; led Israel into idolatry (1 Kings 11:26–40).

Jeshua.note: A high priest who returned with Zerubbabel to rebuild the temple (Ezra 3:2).

Jesse.note: Father of King David; grandson of Ruth and Boaz (Ruth 4:17).

Maachah.note: Name of several individuals; often a wife or mother in royal genealogy (1 Kings 15:2; 2 Chronicles 11:20).

Meshach.note: One of the three Hebrew youths thrown into the fiery furnace (Daniel 3:12).

Nehemiah.note: A governor of Judah who rebuilt Jerusalem’s walls and authored the Book of Nehemiah (Nehemiah 1:1).

Onan.note: Son of Judah who was struck down for disobedience (Genesis 38:9–10).

Maadai.note: One of the family leaders who returned from exile with Zerubbabel (Ezra 8:4).

Maadiah.note: A descendant of Judah listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 9:9).

Maai.note: A musician who participated in the dedication of the Jerusalem wall (Nehemiah 12:36).

Maaseiah.note: A common name for priests, Levites, and other officials (Nehemiah 3:23; Jeremiah 21:1).

Maasiai.note: A Levite listed among the temple servants (Nehemiah 10:9).

Maath.note: An ancestor of Jesus in the genealogy of Luke (Luke 3:26).

Maaz.note: A descendant of Judah listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 2:27).

Machnadebai.note: Not found in Scripture; possibly a misrendered or non-biblical name.

Madai.note: Son of Japheth and ancestor of the Medes (Genesis 10:2).

Magdalene.note: Mary of Magdala, a follower of Jesus who witnessed His resurrection (Matthew 28:1–10).

Magdiel.note: One of the chiefs of Edom (Genesis 36:43).

Magog.note: A descendant of Japheth; traditionally associated with lands north of Israel (Genesis 10:2).

Magpiash.note: Among the leaders of the people who sealed the covenant with NehemiahThe primary reference to Magpiash is found in Nehemiah 10:20.

Mahalah.note: Possibly a variant of Mahlah, one of the daughters of Zelophehad (Numbers 26:33).

Mahali.note: A descendant of Levi and ancestor of one of the Levitical families (1 Chronicles 6:30).

Maharai.note: One of David’s mighty warriors from Netophah (1 Chronicles 11:28).

Mahath.note: A Levite involved in temple restoration under King Josiah (2 Chronicles 34:12).

Malcham.note: A god of the Ammonites, mentioned in connection with the worship of idols (Zephaniah 1:5).

Malchiel.note: A son of Beriah and descendant of Asher (Genesis 46:17).

Mallothi.note: A Levite musician appointed by David (1 Chronicles 25:4).

Malluch.note: A priest or Levite who returned from exile (Nehemiah 10:4).

Manoah.note: Father of Samson, from the tribe of Dan (Judges 13:2).

Mara.note: Name Naomi used for herself meaning 'bitter' after her family’s deaths (Ruth 1:20).

Marcus.note: Also known as John Mark, companion of Paul and Barnabas (Acts 12:12).

Marsena.note: A Persian prince who opposed Esther and was part of the royal council (Esther 1:14).

Matred.note: Mother of Mehetabel, queen and wife of King Hadar of Edom (Genesis 36:39).

Matri.note: The father of Mephibosheth, a descendant of Saul (2 Samuel 9:12).

Mattaniah.note: Zedekiah’s original name before becoming king of Judah (2 Kings 24:17).

Mattatha.note: An ancestor of Jesus in Luke’s genealogy (Luke 3:31).

Matthew.note: Tax collector turned disciple and author of the Gospel of Matthew (Matthew 9:9).

Mebunnai.note: One of David’s mighty warriors (1 Chronicles 11:33).

Medad.note: One of the elders who prophesied in the camp during Moses’ leadership (Numbers 11:26–29).

Medan.note: A son of Abraham by Keturah (Genesis 25:2).

Mehetabel.note: A woman mentioned in Edomite genealogy (Genesis 36:39).

Mehujael.note: A descendant of Cain mentioned in early Genesis genealogy (Genesis 4:18).

Mehuman.note: One of King Xerxes’ seven eunuchs (Esther 1:10).

Melatiah.note: A priest who assisted in the rebuilding of Jerusalem's walls (Nehemiah 3:4).

Melchi.note: An ancestor of Jesus listed in Luke’s genealogy (Luke 3:24).

Melea.note: An ancestor of Jesus in Luke’s genealogy (Luke 3:31).

Memucan.note: One of the seven princes of Persia who advised King Xerxes during the Esther narrative (Esther 1:14).

Menahem.note: A king of Israel who assassinated Shallum (2 Kings 15:14–16).

Menan.note: A member of the genealogical line of Jesus (Luke 3:24).

Mephibosheth.note: Son of Jonathan, a friend of David, and grandson of King Saul (2 Samuel 4:4; 9:6).

Meraioth.note: A priest of the line of Aaron mentioned in the genealogies (1 Chronicles 6:7).

Mered.note: A man who married Bithiah, the daughter of Pharaoh (1 Chronicles 4:17).

Meremoth.note: A priest who helped in the rebuilding of Jerusalem’s walls (Nehemiah 3:4).

Meres.note: A man mentioned in genealogies (1 Chronicles 9:6).

Mesha.note: A king of Moab who rebelled against Israel (2 Kings 3:4–5).

Methusael.note: An ancestor of Lamech in the genealogy of Cain (Genesis 4:18).

Mezahab.note: A descendant of the tribe of Benjamin (1 Chronicles 7:7).

Miamin.note: A descendant of the tribe of Benjamin (1 Chronicles 7:8).

Michri.note: A descendant of the tribe of Benjamin (1 Chronicles 7:7).

Mijamin.note: A descendant of the tribe of Benjamin (1 Chronicles 7:10).

Mishma.note: A son of Ishmael and founder of the Mishmaites (Genesis 25:14).

Mnason.note: A disciple of early Christian faith who hosted Paul in Jerusalem (Acts 21:16).

Malchijah.note: Name of several individuals involved in priestly or rebuilding duties (Nehemiah 3:14; 1 Chronicles 9:12).

Misham.note: A descendant of Elpaal from the tribe of Benjamin (1 Chronicles 8:12).

Mishmannah.note: One of David’s mighty men (1 Chronicles 12:10).

Naphish.note: A son of Ishmael; ancestor of a people group (Genesis 25:15).

Muppim.note: A son of Benjamin and founder of a tribal family (Genesis 46:21).

Naamah.note: Wife of Solomon and mother of Rehoboam (1 Kings 14:21); also a daughter of Lamech (Genesis 4:22).

Naashon.note: A prince of Judah during the Exodus and ancestor of Jesus (Numbers 1:7; Matthew 1:4).

Nabal.note: A wealthy but foolish man who refused to help David and later died suddenly (1 Samuel 25:3–38).

Naaman.note: A Syrian commander healed of leprosy by Elisha (2 Kings 5:1–14).

Naboth.note: Jezreelite who owned a vineyard that King Ahab coveted and had him killed for (1 Kings 21:1–16).

Nadab.note: The eldest son of Aaron, who died without leaving any children (Leviticus 10:1–2).

Nagge.note: Ancestor of Jesus mentioned in Luke’s genealogy (Luke 3:25).

Naharai.note: A servant of David’s warriors, often mentioned in the list of mighty men (2 Samuel 23:28).

Nahbi.note: One of the twelve spies sent to explore Canaan (Numbers 13:14).

Nahshon.note: Another spelling of Naashon, leader of Judah during the Exodus (Numbers 1:7).

Naomi.note: Mother-in-law of Ruth who returned from Moab after her family’s deaths (Ruth 1:2–20).

Narcissus.note: A Christian greeted by Paul in Romans; possibly a prominent believer or household (Romans 16:11).

Nathanael.note: One of Jesus' early disciples, also called Bartholomew in some Gospels (John 1:45–51).

Nehushta.note: The mother of King Jehoiachin of Judah (2 Kings 24:8).

Nekoda.note: A leader among the people of Judah, who returned from Babylonian exile (Ezra 2:48).

Nemuel.note: A Simeonite and descendant of Simeon (Numbers 26:12).

Nepheg.note: A son of David born in Jerusalem (2 Samuel 5:15).

Ner.note: Father of Kish and grandfather of Saul, the first king of Israel (1 Samuel 14:51).

Nereus.note: A Christian greeted by Paul in his letter to the Romans (Romans 16:15).

Neri.note: The father of Zerubbabel, a leader who returned with the exiles (1 Chronicles 3:19).

Neriah.note: Father of Baruch, the scribe of the prophet Jeremiah (Jeremiah 32:12).

Nethaneel.note: A leader from the tribe of Issachar and also a Levite musician (Numbers 1:8; 1 Chronicles 25:2).

Nethaniah.note: Father of Ishmael who murdered Gedaliah, governor of Judah (2 Kings 25:25).

Nicanor.note: A friend of Paul’s and one of the first seven deacons chosen in the early church (Acts 6:5).

Nicodemus.note: A Pharisee who visited Jesus at night and later defended Him (John 3:1–21; 19:39).

Nicolas.note: One of the seven deacons appointed by the apostles (Acts 6:5).

Nimrod.note: A mighty hunter and early king who built cities like Babel (Genesis 10:8–10).

Nimshi.note: The father of Jehu, king of Israel (1 Kings 19:16).

Noah.note: A righteous man who built the ark and survived the flood (Genesis 6–9).

Noe.note: Another name for Noah, the righteous man who survived the flood (Genesis 5:29).

Non.note: Father of Joshua, who succeeded Moses as leader of Israel (Numbers 13:8).

Nun.note: Father of Joshua, leader of Israel after Moses (Numbers 13:8).

Nymphas.note: A Christian mentioned in the letter to the Colossians, likely a church leader (Colossians 4:15).

Obal.note: A son of Joktan, listed in the genealogies of Genesis (Genesis 10:28).

Obed.note: Son of Boaz and Ruth, grandfather of David (Ruth 4:17).

Obil.note: An Ishmaelite overseer of David’s camels (1 Chronicles 27:30).

Ocran.note: The father of Abijah, the king of Judah, a descendant of David (1 Chronicles 3:10).

Og.note: King of Bashan, defeated by Moses and Israel (Deuteronomy 3:1–11).

Ohad.note: A son of Simeon, listed among the tribal genealogies (Genesis 46:10).

Olympas.note: A Christian greeted by Paul in his letter to the Romans (Romans 16:15).

Omar.note: A descendant of Judah, mentioned in genealogies (1 Chronicles 4:19).

Omri.note: King of Israel who founded Samaria and did evil in God’s eyes (1 Kings 16:21–28).

Onam.note: A descendant of Judah, son of Jerahmeel (1 Chronicles 2:26).

Onesimus.note: A runaway slave who became a Christian and was commended by Paul (Philemon 1:10–16).

Onesiphorus.note: A faithful Christian who refreshed Paul during his imprisonment (2 Timothy 1:16).

Oreb.note: A leader of the Midianites defeated by the Israelites (Judges 7:25).

Ornan.note: A Jebusite who sold his threshing floor to David for the temple site (1 Chronicles 21:22–25).

Orpah.note: Daughter-in-law of Naomi who returned to her people instead of following Ruth (Ruth 1:14).

Oshea.note: Original name of Joshua, son of Nun (Numbers 13:8, 16).

Othni.note: A descendant of Levi from the Gershonite clan (1 Chronicles 6:40).

Othniel.note: First judge of Israel, nephew of Caleb, who delivered Israel from Cushan-Rishathaim (Judges 3:9–11).

Ozem.note: One of David’s brothers, son of Jesse (1 Chronicles 2:15).

Ozias.note: Greek form of Uzziah, king of Judah who reigned for 52 years (Matthew 1:8; 2 Chronicles 26:3).

Ozni.note: A descendant of Simeon, mentioned in genealogies (1 Chronicles 4:36).

Paarai.note: A Levite who helped restore worship in the time of King Josiah (2 Chronicles 23:18).

Padon.note: Ancestor of temple servants who returned from exile (Ezra 2:44).

Pagiel.note: Leader of the tribe of Asher during the wilderness journey (Numbers 1:13).

Palal.note: One of the men who repaired a section of Jerusalem’s wall (Nehemiah 3:25).

Pallu.note: Son of Reuben and ancestor of the Palluites (Genesis 46:9).

Palti.note: One of the twelve spies sent to explore Canaan (Numbers 13:9).

Paltiel.note: Son of Laish; briefly given Michal, David’s wife, by Saul (1 Samuel 25:44).

Parmashta.note: A Persian official who helped defeat the enemies of Esther (Esther 3:12).

Parmenas.note: One of the seven chosen to serve the early church (Acts 6:5).

Parnach.note: A Levite mentioned in genealogies (1 Chronicles 6:54).

Parosh.note: A descendant of Judah mentioned in the genealogies (Ezra 2:3).

Parshandatha.note: One of Haman’s ten sons killed by the Jews (Esther 9:7).

Paruah.note: A district officer under King Solomon (1 Kings 4:17).

Pasach.note: A descendant of Japhlet, from the tribe of Asher (1 Chronicles 7:33).

Paseah.note: Ancestor of temple servants and a leader in wall restoration (Ezra 2:49; Nehemiah 3:6).

Pashur.note: A priest who opposed Jeremiah and was struck with terror (Jeremiah 20:1–6).

Patrobas.note: A Christian greeted by Paul in Romans (Romans 16:14).

Paul.note: Apostle to the Gentiles, author of many New Testament epistles (Acts 13–28).

Paulus.note: A Roman official, also known as Sergius Paulus, who became a believer after hearing Paul’s teaching (Acts 13:7).

Pedahzur.note: Father of Gamaliel, leader of the tribe of Manasseh (Numbers 1:10).

Pedaiah.note: Name of multiple individuals, including a temple treasurer (2 Kings 23:36; Nehemiah 8:4).

Pekah.note: King of Israel who reigned during the time of King Ahaz of Judah (2 Kings 15:27–31).

Pekahiah.note: Son of Menahem and king of Israel; assassinated after two years (2 Kings 15:22–25).

Pelaiah.note: A descendant of Simeon listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 4:42).

Pelaliah.note: A priest involved in the public reading of the Law (Nehemiah 8:7).

Pelatiah.note: A prince of the people of Judah, mentioned in Ezekiel’s vision (Ezekiel 11:1).

Peleg.note: Son of Eber; 'in his days the earth was divided' (Genesis 10:25).

Peninnah.note: The second wife of Elkanah, who provoked Hannah to jealousy (1 Samuel 1:6).

Persis.note: A Christian woman praised by Paul for her hard work in the Lord (Romans 16:12).

Peter.note: One of Jesus’ closest disciples, also called Simon; leader in the early church (Matthew 4:18; Acts 2:14).

Pethuel.note: The father of the prophet Joel (Joel 1:1).

Peulthai.note: A Levite mentioned in genealogies (1 Chronicles 9:4).

Phallu.note: A descendant of Reuben, listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 5:3).

Phanuel.note: Father of Anna the prophetess who met the baby Jesus (Luke 2:36).

Pharaoh.note: Title of Egyptian kings; many are mentioned throughout the Old Testament (Exodus 1:8).

Pharez.note: Alternate spelling of Perez, son of Judah (Genesis 46:12).

Phebe.note: A deacon of the church in Cenchrea and helper of many, including Paul (Romans 16:1–2).

Phichol.note: The commander of King Abimelech’s army who interacted with Abraham (Genesis 21:22).

Philemon.note: A Christian to whom Paul wrote a letter concerning the slave Onesimus (Philemon 1:1).

Philetus.note: A false teacher who rejected the resurrection (2 Timothy 2:17–18).

Philip.note: One of the twelve apostles; also a deacon who preached in Samaria (John 1:43; Acts 8:5).

Philologus.note: A Christian greeted by Paul in his letter to the Romans (Romans 16:15).

Phinehas.note: Son of Eleazar, known for his zeal in stopping Israel’s sin (Numbers 25:7–13).

Phlegon.note: A Christian greeted by Paul in Romans (Romans 16:14).

Phurah.note: Gideon’s servant who accompanied him to spy on the Midianites (Judges 7:10–11).

Phygellus.note: A Christian who turned away from Paul in Asia (2 Timothy 1:15).

Pilate.note: Roman governor who authorized Jesus’ crucifixion (Matthew 27:2, 24).

Pildash.note: A son of Nahor, brother of Abraham (Genesis 22:22).

Pinon.note: A descendant of Reuben, listed in genealogies (1 Chronicles 5:19).

Piram.note: One of the five Amorite kings defeated by Joshua at the battle of Gibeon (Joshua 10:5).

Pithon.note: A descendant of the tribe of Benjamin (1 Chronicles 8:36).

Pochereth.note: One of the descendants of the Temple servants (Ezra 2:57).

Pontius.note: The governor of Judea who sentenced Jesus to be crucified (Luke 23:1–25).

Poratha.note: One of Haman’s sons killed by the Jews (Esther 9:7).

Potiphar.note: Egyptian official who bought Joseph as a slave (Genesis 39:1).

Prisca.note: A prominent early Christian mentioned alongside her husband Aquila, who worked with Paul (Acts 18:2–3).

Priscilla.note: Early Christian woman and co-worker with Paul; wife of Aquila (Acts 18:2, 18).

Prochorus.note: One of the seven men chosen to serve in the early church (Acts 6:5).

Puah.note: One of the Hebrew midwives who disobeyed Pharaoh’s orders and saved the children (Exodus 1:15–21).

Publius.note: The chief official of the island of Malta who welcomed Paul (Acts 28:7).

Pudens.note: A Christian mentioned in Paul’s letters, possibly associated with the early Roman church (2 Timothy 4:21).

Pul.note: A king of Assyria who invaded Israel during the reign of Menahem (2 Kings 15:19).

Putiel.note: Putiel is a name that appears only once in the Bible, as the father of the wife of Eleazar, the son of Aaron and the father of Phinehas. Exodus 6:25

Riphath.note: A son of Gomer, mentioned in genealogies (Genesis 10:3).

Raamah.note: A son of Cush, mentioned in genealogies (Genesis 10:7).

Raguel.note: Father-in-law of Moses, also known as Jethro (Exodus 2:18).

Sabtah.note: A son of Cush, mentioned in genealogies (Genesis 10:7).

Togarmah.note: A son of Gomer, mentioned in genealogies (Genesis 10:3).

Tubal.note: A son of Japheth, mentioned in genealogies (Genesis 10:2).

Tychicus.note: A companion of Paul who delivered letters and provided encouragement (Acts 20:4; Ephesians 6:21).

Tamar.note: Daughter-in-law of Judah who bore him twins, Perez and Zerah (Genesis 38:6–0).

Terah.note: Father of Abraham, Nahor, and Haran (Genesis 11:26).

Teresh.note: One of the two eunuchs who conspired to assassinate King Ahasuerus (Esther 2:21).

Tertius.note: The amanuensis (secretary) who wrote Paul’s letter to the Romans (Romans 16:22).

Tertullus.note: A lawyer who accused Paul before Felix (Acts 24:1).

Thaddeus.note: One of the twelve apostles, also known as Judas, son of James (Luke 6:16).

Theophilus.note: A person to whom Luke addressed his Gospel and the Book of Acts (Luke 1:3; Acts 1:1).

Tiras.note: A son of Japheth, mentioned in genealogies (Genesis 10:2).

Tobiah.note: An Ammonite official who opposed Nehemiah's efforts to rebuild Jerusalem (Nehemiah 2:10).

Ashkenaz.note: A son of Gomer, mentioned in genealogies (Genesis 10:3).

Samlah of Masrekah.note: A king of Edom, mentioned in genealogies (Genesis 36:36).

Shaul of Rehoboth.note: A king of Edom, mentioned in genealogies (Genesis 36:37).

Sarai.note: Wife of Abraham and mother of Isaac, later named Sarah (Genesis 11:29).

Shamgar.note: A judge of Israel who killed 600 Philistines with an ox goad (Judges 3:31).

Shaphan.note: Scribe in King Josiah’s court who helped initiate religious reforms (2 Kings 22:3–10).

Sheleph.note: A son of Joktan, mentioned in genealogies (Genesis 10:26).

Shema.note: A descendant of Levi, mentioned in genealogies (1 Chronicles 6:44).

Shemer.note: Owner of the hill purchased by Omri to build Samaria (1 Kings 16:24).

Sherebiah.note: a Levite and a priest who lived in the time of Ezra and Nehemiah. His name means 'Jehovah has scorched' or 'Jehovah is originator' . He was one of the Levites who helped Ezra to bring the gold and silver from Persia to Jerusalem. He also assisted Ezra in reading the law to the people and signed the covenant with Nehemiah. He had eighteen sons and brethren, and was probably a family of singers.

Serug.note: A descendant of Shem, mentioned in genealogies (Genesis 11:22).

Sheshbazzar.note: A leader of the first group of exiles returning to Jerusalem (Ezra 1:8).

Sheshan.note: A descendant of Judah who had a daughter named Ahlai (1 Chronicles 2:31).

Shimeah.note: A descendant of David, mentioned in genealogies (1 Chronicles 3:22).

Ziphion.note: A son of Gad and ancestor of a tribe in Israel (Genesis 46:16).

Zabud.note: One of Solomon’s officials, serving as the king’s friend and advisor (1 Kings 4:5).

Zerah.note: The twin brother of Pharez, son of Judah (Genesis 38:30).

Zeresh.note: Wife of Haman, who advised him to build gallows for Mordecai (Esther 5:10).

Zerubbabel.note: Governor of Judah who led the first group of exiles back to Jerusalem (Ezra 2:2).

Zia.note: A descendant of the tribe of Judah (1 Chronicles 4:20).

Zibeon.note: A Hivite chief and father of Aiah (Genesis 36:2).

Zebadiah.note: A Levite mentioned in genealogies (1 Chronicles 23:20).

Zebedee.note: Father of James and John, the apostles (Matthew 4:21).

Zizah.note: A member of the tribe of Judah mentioned in genealogies (1 Chronicles 4:6).

Zillah.note: The wife of Lamech and mother of Jubal and Tubal-cain (Genesis 4:19–22).

Zimri.note: A king of Israel who assassinated the previous king (1 Kings 16:9–20).
